Operation 'getCertificateDetailByCertIdentifier' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary is generic and doesn't convey the dual purpose (status checking and detail retrieval). Description is repetitive and unclear about what is actually returned. Improved summary specifies both status and details retrieval. Enhanced description clarifies the operation's purpose, use cases, return value (Certificate object), and provides clearer parameter context. Better AI agent interpretability for determining when to use this operation.

data.current_description:
Once the certificate order has been created, this method can be used to check the status of the certificate. This method can also be used to retrieve details of the certificate.
  • **shopperId** is **not the same** as **customerId**. **shopperId** is a number of max length 10 digits (*ex:* 1234567890) whereas **customerId** is a UUIDv4 (*ex:* 295e3bc3-b3b9-4d95-aae5-ede41a994d13)
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve certificate status and details by identifier

message: Operation 'certificate_create' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Original summary is vague about the asynchronous nature. Description is unclear about inputs (CertificateCreate schema), outputs (202 response with certificateId), and doesn't clearly explain the two monitoring options. Enhanced version specifies request/response details and clarifies the polling vs callback mechanisms for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_summary: Create a pending order for certificate
data.current_description: Creating a certificate order can be a long running asynchronous operation in the PKI workflow. The PKI API supports 2 options for getting the completion stateful actions for this asynchronous operations: 1) by polling operations -- see /v1/certificates/{certificateId}/actions 2) via WebHook style callback -- see '/v1/certificates/{certificateId}/callback'.
data.summary_suggestion: Create a new certificate order asynchronously
data.description_suggestion: Creates a new certificate order and returns a 202 Accepted response with a certificateId. This is an asynchronous operation in the PKI workflow. The request body must contain certificate details as defined in CertificateCreate schema. Monitor completion using either polling via GET /v1/certificates/{certificateId}/actions or by registering a webhook callback via PUT /v1/certificates/{certificateId}/callback. The callback will receive POST requests with CertificateAction details for each lifecycle event.
data.reasoning: Original summary is vague about the asynchronous nature. Description is unclear about inputs (CertificateCreate schema), outputs (202 response with certificateId), and doesn't clearly explain the two monitoring options. Enhanced version specifies request/response details and clarifies the polling vs callback mechanisms for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: Unregister the callback for a particular certificate.
data.description_suggestion: Removes the webhook callback registration for a certificate. After deletion, the system will no longer send POST requests to the previously registered callback URL for certificate lifecycle events. Subsequent certificate actions will not trigger webhook notifications until a new callback is registered.

message: Operation 'certificate_renew' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Original summary is too generic. Description is verbose but lacks clarity on inputs/outputs and side effects. Added specificity about timing windows, input requirements (CertificateRenew schema), return value, and important behavioral notes about SANs for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: Renewal is the process by which the validity of a certificate is extended. Renewal is only available 60 days prior to expiration of the previous certificate and 30 days after the expiration of the previous certificate. The renewal supports modifying a set of the original certificate order information. Once a request is validated and approved, the certificate will be issued with extended validity. Since subject alternative names can be removed during a renewal, we require that you provide the subject alternative names you expect in the renewed certificate. New names added to a certificate that do not share the base domain of the common name may take additional time to validate.
data.summary_suggestion: Extend certificate validity with optional modifications
data.description_suggestion: Extends the validity period of an active certificate by submitting a renewal request. Renewal is available 60 days before expiration through 30 days after expiration. Accepts CertificateRenew object to modify certificate order information including subject alternative names. Returns the renewed certificate with extended validity period. Note: Subject alternative names must be explicitly provided as removals are supported; new names not sharing the base domain may require additional validation time.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too generic. Description is verbose but lacks clarity on inputs/outputs and side effects. Added specificity about timing windows, input requirements (CertificateRenew schema), return value, and important behavioral notes about SANs for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: Use revoke call to revoke an active certificate, if the certificate has not been issued a 404 response will be returned.

Returns success confirmation. Returns 404 if the certificate has not been issued. This action is irreversible and will immediately disable the certificate.

message: Operation 'certificate_siteseal_get' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Summary is too terse ('Get Site seal'). data.current_description: This method is used to obtain the site seal information for an issued certificate. A site seal is a graphic that the certificate purchaser can embed on their web site to show their visitors information about their SSL certificate. If a web site visitor clicks on the site seal image, a pop-up page is displayed that contains detailed information about the SSL certificate. The site seal token is used to link the site seal graphic image to the appropriate certificate details pop-up page display when a user clicks on the site seal. The site seal images are expected to be static images and hosted on the reseller's website, to minimize delays for customer page load times.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve site seal information for certificate
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves site seal information for an issued certificate, including the site seal token and graphic details. The site seal is an embeddable graphic that displays SSL certificate information to website visitors; clicking it opens a pop-up with detailed certificate details. The site seal token links the graphic to the appropriate certificate details page. Site seal images are static and should be hosted on the reseller's website to optimize page load times. Requires certificateId and optional parameters for customization.
data.reasoning: Summary is too terse ('Get Site seal'). Description is verbose and marketing-focused rather than technical. Reorganized to clarify what is returned (site seal token and graphic details), the purpose (embeddable graphic), and the technical requirement (static hosting). Added reference to required parameters for AI agent clarity.

message: Operation 'certificate_reissue' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects, poor_ai_interpretability. Summary doesn't clearly distinguish between rekeying and domain reissuing. Description is verbose with HTML tags and lacks clear output information. Enhanced version clarifies the two reissue types, specifies the request/response schemas, and highlights the critical side effect of replacing pending reissues for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: Rekeying is the process by which the private and public key is changed for a certificate. It is a simplified reissue,where only the CSR is changed. Reissuing is the process by which domain names are added or removed from a certificate.Once a request is validated and approved, the certificate will be reissued with the new common name and sans specified. Unlimited reissues are available during the lifetime of the certificate.New names added to a certificate that do not share the base domain of the common name may take additional time to validate. If this API call is made before a previous pending reissue has been validated and issued, the previous reissue request is automatically rejected and replaced with the current request.
data.summary_suggestion: Reissue certificate with new domains or key
data.description_suggestion: Reissues an active certificate to change the private/public key (rekeying) or modify domain names (add/remove SANs). Accepts a CertificateReissue request object specifying the new CSR and/or domain configuration. Returns the reissued certificate object. After validation and approval, the certificate will be reissued with the specified common name and SANs. Unlimited reissues are available during the certificate lifetime. New domains not sharing the base domain may require additional validation time. Important: If a previous reissue request is pending, this call will automatically reject and replace it with the current request.
data.reasoning: Summary doesn't clearly distinguish between rekeying and domain reissuing. Description is verbose with HTML tags and lacks clear output information. Enhanced version clarifies the two reissue types, specifies the request/response schemas, and highlights the critical side effect of replacing pending reissues for better AI agent decision-making.
